sen.j: 城代（じょうだい）とは、城主の留守中に代理として城を管理した者。
sen.e: The jodai is a person who took care of a castle on behalf of the lord of the castle in the absence of the lord.

sen.e: There are other descriptions such as Rusuigashira (留守居頭) and Orusui (大留守居).

sen.j: 戦国時代_(日本)に大名直轄の城の管理・政務・防衛にあたった家臣を指した。
sen.e: In the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan), a vassal was referred to as jodai when the vassal was assigned to take care of a castle directly controlled/managed by a daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) and administrative affairs and protect the castle from attacks.

sen.j: 江戸幕府は駿府城･二条城･伏見城･大坂城の4城に城代を設置した（元和_(日本)5年（1619年）に伏見城代は廃止）。
sen.e: The Edo Bakufu established four jodai for Sunpu Castle, Nijo Castle, Fushimi Castle and Osaka Castle (the jodai for Fushimi Castle was discontinued in 1619.)

sen.j: また、諸藩においては、藩主が参勤交代で不在の折に留守居の職にあった家臣（一般には家老がその職務にあたった）を特に城代家老と呼んだ。
sen.e: Where its feudal lord was away to Edo due to the Sankinkotai (a system under which feudal lards in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo), a vassal who had to take care of the castle during the absence of the lord was particularly called Jodai-garo (usually, a chief retainer was assigned to exercise the duties.)
